tossups.question: This author created the fictional show Twice a Week or More, which is actually broadcast three times a week and offers the chance to maintain “the best of taste” in the absence of meetings of the Hayes Society. One of this author’s characters borrows his new boss’s car for a “motoring trip” on which he visits Mrs. Benn. This author wrote a novel whose characters go to Norfolk because they believe that lost things go there and who end up finding a (*) cassette. One of this author’s protagonists earnestly tries to become better at “the key to human worth,” banter. In a novel by this author, Madame reveals that “deferrals” never existed. This author who wrote about Lord Darlington’s butler Stevens also created Kathy, Ruth, and Tommy, clones raised to be organ donors. For 10 points, name this recent Nobel Laureate who wrote The Remains of the Day and Never Let Me Go.

This person wrote a treatise called “The Only Way” where he laid out methods, like teaching songs, that he would later use to pacify the “Land of War.” This person created a settlement at Cumana that was undercut by a slave raid conducted by Gonzalo Ocampo. Laws sponsored by this non-monarch led to the revolt of Gonzalo Pizarro. This person engineered the replacement of the Laws of Burgos with the “New Laws.” Some historians blame this person for writing the earliest works perpetuating the (*) “Black Legend.” This person argued against Juan de Sepulveda’s claims that a certain group were “natural slaves” in the Valladolid Debate. Earlier, he was Bishop of Chiapas and Protector of the Indians. For 10 points, name this Dominican Friar who wrote of the Spanish brutality in the New World in his A Short Account of the Destruction of the Indies.

`Abdu'l-Bahá identifies the “two witnesses” in this work as Muhammad and Ali. Near the beginning of this work, various groups are admonished for eating foods that have been sacrificed to idols. A city described in this work has foundation stones with names inscribed upon them as well as a wondrous tree with twelve types of fruit. During an interlude in this work, the narrator is instructed to eat a scroll. This section of a larger text mentions a (*) dragon waiting to devour the child of a woman who is giving birth. This book was written by a disputed figure who self-identifies as “John of Patmos.” This book also describes a seven-horned lamb, the blowing of seven trumpets, and the opening of seven seals. For ten points, name this book of the New Testament that describes the end of days.
tossups.answer: Book of Revelation to John [prompt on “New Testament” until mentioned; do not accept or prompt on “Book of Revelations”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Book of Revelation to John [prompt on “New Testament” until mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "“Book of Revelations”"]

tossups.question: It’s not Lully, but the work Les gouts-reunis, or “the styles reunited,” features a trio sonata written in honor of this composer. This composer helped establish the slow-fast-slow-fast movement pattern for church sonatas. Simultaneously playing a delayed leading tone and an anticipated tonic is called this composer’s “cadence” or “clash.” This subject of an (*) “apotheosis” by François Couperin names Rachmaninoff’s Opus 42 dedicated to Fritz Kreisler; Rachmaninoff only learned after publishing the work that the relevant “theme” was not originally by this composer but was instead the Spanish tune “La Folia.” For 10 points, name this Italian Baroque composer of the Christmas Concerto.

In one parody by this author, Love indicates his approval to a young couple by sneezing. One of this author’s poems reviles a miser who has neither “beetles nor spiders nor fire,” has a “body drier than bone,” and believes that “sufficiency is riches.” In one poem, this man harangues a friend who is stealing his napkins. This poet laments that his girlfriend’s eyes are red with weeping in one poem; he tells that girl to “give me a thousand kisses” because “night is one long everlasting sleep” in a poem beginning (*) “Let us live… let us love.” This poet threatened to sodomize Furius and Aurelius in Carmen 16. “I hate and I love...I feel it happening and I am tormented” was written by this poet, who mourned the death of his lover’s sparrow in another work. For 10 points, name this Roman poet who wrote “Hail and farewell” and addressed many poems to Lesbia.

The artist of this painting chose one of his sitters after grabbing his hand and staring at it fascinatedly for a while. This painting’s style was inspired by the artist’s trip to Munich, which separated it from his earlier Impressionistic work. A photograph named “[this painting], Washington, D. C.” shows an African-American woman with a broom and a mop in front of the American flag; that photograph is by Gordon Parks. One curl escapes the bun of a woman wearing a (*) cameo and a dotted dress in this painting. The central figures of this painting are either husband and wife or father and daughter, and the window above them is mirrored by a pitchfork held by a dentist. For ten points, name this oft-parodied Grant Wood painting showing a serious-looking couple in front of an house in Iowa.

Frederick William I received a regiment of dragoons in exchange for giving some of this substance to another ruler. An early company producing this substance created a simple crossed swords logo in 1722 to protect its product. An early recipe for creating this substance included kaolin and alabaster. It was first created in Europe by Ehrenfried von Tschirnhaus, who had a factory for producing this substance in Meissen. The Zwinger Palace holds 20,000 objects made from this substance collected by Augustus the Strong in (*) Dresden. An octagonal tower made with this namesake substance and destroyed in the Taiping rebellion was located in Nanjing. This substance can be made from bone ash and comes in “soft-paste” and “hard paste” versions. For 10 points, name this ceramic material which was exported to Europe in blue and white bowls from Ming China.
tossups.answer: porcelain [prompt on “pottery”; prompt on “china” until mention; prompt on “ceramics” until mention]
tossups.answer_formatted: porcelain [prompt on “pottery”; prompt on “china” until mention; prompt on “ceramics” until mention]

tossups.question: One model for explaining the distribution of this quantity in the galactic disk assumes the instantaneous recycling approximation and ignores both infall and outflow. The non-existence of objects with low values of this quantity in the Closed-Box model is referred to as the G-Dwarf Problem. Objects with very low values of this quantity can hypothetically undergo runaway pair-production, resulting in core collapse. Hypothetical objects for which this value is zero are called (*) “population III” and were created soon after the Big Bang. It is either symbolized Z or measured as the log base 10 of iron over hydrogen for the object in question minus said calculation for the sun. For 10 points, name this property, the fraction of a star’s mass that isn’t hydrogen or helium.

This actress appears with her actor husband in a Samsung advertisement where she uses a melon baller. She plays Kenneth’s dead girlfriend in a movie based on a magazine’s wanted ad for time travel. After encouraging the growth of the cult classic, The Room, this actress appeared in this year’s The Disaster Artist. In one episode of her most recent TV vehicle, she admits that she “might actually be into Tahani.” Her first TV show (*) went off air after its third season, when the studio forced the creator to replace the season-long plots the show was known for in favor of shorter mysteries. She plays Leslie Knope’s Eagleton counterpart for several episodes of Parks and Recreation and her voice can be heard at the end of every Gossip Girl episode. For 10 points, name this actress who played the title character in Veronica Mars and was the voice of Anna in Frozen.

A symmetrical lattice can be used to design a network of these objects with diagonally-crossed shunt elements; this expands on their ladder topology. Two opposing ones of these objects are added in the Linkwitz-Riley version of them. The Sallen-Key topology can be used to design these objects and calculate the poles and zeros of their transfer functions. These objects come in Chebyshev and (*) Butterworth varieties. Their ringing and quality factor can be read from Bode plots of their magnitude and phase, which show minus 3 decibel gain at a cutoff value but can never be an ideal step function. The simplest types of these things are created out of a resistor and a capacitor, and can come in notch, band-pass, and high-pass varieties. For ten points, name these structures which remove unwanted frequencies from a signal.

This figure fell in love with a woman who was born with the Vedas in her memory, but she cut off her hair and lit herself on fire in response. After attempting to lift Mount Meru and disturbing Shiva and Parvati, Shiva crushed this figure’s arms. He commanded all heavenly bodies to fall into place during the birth of his son, and all obeyed except Saturn; that son of this figure wielded a noose that transformed into coiling snakes and got his name from defeating a (*) thunder god. In revenge for his sister’s nose and ears being cut off, this figure was assisted by the demon Maricha in kidnapping a princess, leading to a war with the prince of Ayodhya. For 10 points, name this figure usually depicted with ten heads, a Rakshasa who kidnaps Sita, the villain of the Ramayana.

A Joan Didion essay titled “[this politician] Agonistes” notes how Jesse Jackson once referred to him as “nothing but an appetite.” This politician was advised on race issues by the former president of the National Urban League, Vernon Jordan. Civil rights activists criticized this person for rushing home from a primary to supervise the execution of a brain-damaged African-American man, Ricky Ray Rector. In a speech to the Rainbow Coalition, this politician criticized the (*) rapper Sister Souljah for her remarks on the Rodney King riots. This politician, who promised to “end welfare as we have come to know it,” was called “our first black president” by Toni Morrison at the height of a scandal involving Paula Jones and Gennifer Flowers. For 10 points, name this president who had a good relationship with the black community despite the Monica Lewinsky scandal.

Mixing this compound with rhodium (III) chloride creates a complex used for cyclopropanation of alkenes, where this compound exists as a bridging ligand. One process for producing this compound occurs in an adiabatic flash tank and must stop precipitation of the tri-iodide intermediate. A vinyl derivative of this compound is polymerized into Elmer’s glue. An anhydrous form of it forms crystals below 16.6 degrees Celsius and is commonly used for (*) recrystallization. A square planar iridium catalyst is used in the main industrial process for manufacturing this compound. The Cativa and Monsanto processes produce this compound by carbonylation of methanol, and its pure form is called “glacial.” For 10 points, name this acid found in vinegar.

One thinker punned on a notion central to this philosopher by respelling its name without the initial letter, thus making it look like the Latin for “look.” Catherine Pickstock and John Milbank are among a set of Cambridge thinkers whose animating philosophy is that this thinker can be blamed for ushering in modernity – that group is the Radical Orthodox School. This philosopher coined the name for a position that claims that properties have the same meaning when applied to God as when applied to non-divine beings. That is (*) univocity of being. This philosopher’s followers coined a term for the particular traits that individuate something, its haecceity (hek-see-uh-tee). For 10 points, name this medieval philosopher, author of the Ordinatio, who was often called Doctor Subtilis.
tossups.answer: John Duns Scotus [accept “Doctor Subtilis” before mention]

tossups.question: Deletion of genes involved in this process was recently shown to inhibit white adipocyte differentiation and promote brown adipocyte transdifferentiation. mTOR (em-TOR) is thought to downregulate this process through phosphorylation of the ULK complex. Adaptor proteins for this process such as p62 and NBR1 commonly possess a LIR motif, which selectively binds to the Atg8 family of proteins. An assay for this process can be performed by immunoblotting for LC3-II turnover during the (*) starvation-induced form of this process. The “macro” form of this process involves a formation of a double membrane around the cytoplasmic target, which can then fuse with the lysosome for degradation. For 10 points, name this process in which a cell digests its own components for energy.
tossups.answer: autophagy [or autophagocytosis, or macroautophagy or microautophagy]

tossups.question: Due to anger about missile testing, Peter Greyson dumped red paint on a physical copy of this document. This document can be altered using the 7/50 (seven-fifty) formula, and it is subject to he “Living Tree Doctrine.” Parts of this document can be overridden under the “notwithstanding clause.” The “Beau risque” strategy supported changes in this document that René Lévesque (le-VEK) had earlier tried to veto. A crisis over it was triggered due to the use of “ministers without portfolio” when Julian (*) Byng refused to dissolve Parliament. This document’s Charter of Rights and Freedoms was passed as part of its 1982 repatriation. The Meech Lake Accord and Charlottetown Accord were both failed attempts to amend this document. For 10 points, name this document that provides the framework for the governance of a country with a capital at Ottawa.
tossups.answer: Canadian Constitution [or Constitution Act 1982; Constitution Act 1867; Canada Act 1982; accept Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms before mention; prompt on “The Constitution”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Canadian Constitution [or Constitution Act 1982; Constitution Act 1867; Canada Act 1982; accept Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms before mention; prompt on “The Constitution”]
acceptable: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

tossups.question: This opera pioneered the usage of the vibraphone in the orchestra instead of purely in jazz compositions. One character in this opera notably responds to a declaration of love by murmuring "I poisoned your mother"; that character also asks "Isn't that the sofa on which your father bled to death?" in a spoken line marked casual, or “beiläufig.” In one scene from Act III of this opera, a crowd panics in the (*) gaming room after learning the price of Jungfrau cable railway shares has collapsed. The central character of this opera is admired by characters like the Countess Geschewitz, Alwa, and Alwa's father, Dr. Schon; that character is finally killed by her client Jack the Ripper. For 10 points, name this opera about the title courtesan, by Alban Berg.

In this work, after some children plan to stab one of their classmates with nails, one girl tells him, “Your father is a murderer but it’s not your fault, so I forgive you.” Because her father has a Cadillac, her family’s maid doesn’t eat with them, and her grandmother’s knees hurt, this novel’s protagonist wants to be a prophet. The narrator is briefly homeless after Markus leaves her, and for her college thesis, she has to design a religious-themed amusement park with her husband (*) Reza, whom she divorces. The narrator’s parents participate in protests in this work until missile strikes cause them to send her to a boarding school in Vienna. The protagonist describes leaving her grandmother in this book, which begins with the section “The Veil.” For 10 points, name this graphic memoir following Marjane Satrapi’s childhood during the Iranian revolution.

The precedent for this requirement established in Frothingham v. Mellon was overturned in Flast v. Cohen, which resulted in the Flast Test for determining if taxpayers meet this requirement. Justices Louis Brandeis and Felix Frankfurter pushed for restricting the scope of this concept from public rights to private rights to prevent cases like Fairchild v. Hughes. The “cognizability” requirement seeks to prevent parties not directly (*) related to the violation of “legally protected rights” from meeting it. The 1992 Supreme Court case Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife established the three part test that established how to meet this requirement, including the need for an “injury in fact.” The most basic qualification for “having” this concept is that a law or action has provably harmed a plaintiff and is redressable through the courts. For 10 points, name this eligibility of a party to file a suit in court.
tossups.answer: standing [or locus standi; accept answers like having standing]

tossups.question: An author of this ethnicity reminisces about covering all her school paintings in black and remaining silent during kindergarten, then bullying another girl who also refuses to talk. One character of this ethnicity is fired for putting wind-up toys in sexual positions with Barbie dolls. An author of this ethnicity wrote about a girl who falls into a lake during a festival and realizes that one of its performers is a cross-dresser; that girl later helps Lena to leave her husband. This is the ethnicity of the author of (*) Tripmaster Monkey, who wrote about her mother’s stories of white “ghosts” and the “No Name Woman” in her memoir The Woman Warrior. This is the ethnicity of an author who wrote about four mother-daughter pairs playing mahjong in The Joy Luck Club. For 10 points, name this ethnicity of Maxine Hong Kingston and Amy Tan.
tossups.answer: Chinese-American [prompt on partial answer or on “Asian” or “Asian-American”] Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: The Chicago Cubs made headlines in 2016 after winning their first World Series in 108 years. For 10 points each, answer the following about other teams and their championship droughts.
parts: This cross-town rival of the Cubs broke an 88-year drought after they defeated the Astros in the 2005 World Series.

In 2004, the Boston Red Sox won their first World Series in 86 years, breaking Babe Ruth’s supposed “curse.” This sportswriter at the Boston Globe popularized the legend with his book The Curse of the Bambino.
Led by MVP Mike Schmidt and Cy Young winner Steve Carlton, this team beat the Kansas City Royals in the 1980 World Series to secure their first title in 77 years.

bonuses.leadin: This poet wrote about a “drone… getting drunk with silver honey” to “curl forever in some far-off farmyard flower” in “Beehive.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet who wrote about his home state, describing a fire in the “sacred whisper of the pines” in “Georgia Dusk.” He also included stories like “Kabnis” and “Blood-Burning Moon” in one collection.

This other Harlem Renaissance poet wrote about “tangerines and mangoes and grape fruit” inspiring homesickness for Jamaica in “The Tropics in New York.” He expressed a wish to “face the murderous, cowardly pack” in “If We Must Die.”
This best-known Harlem Renaissance poet wrote “The Weary Blues” and “The Negro Speaks of Rivers.”

bonuses.leadin: This general decided to study theology after getting into an argument with Robert Ingersoll while riding a train to Indianapolis for a veterans’ reunion. For 10 points each:
answers: Lew Wallace [or Lewis Wallace] [Yeah, this is the guy who wrote Ben Hur]
Billy the Kid [or William H. Bonney; or Henry McCarty]
parts: Name this Union general who was mocked for marching his division down the wrong path at the Battle of Shiloh. His troops later held up Jubal Early’s cavalry at the Battle of Monocacy, preventing a raid on D.C.

While serving as governor of the New Mexico Territory, Lew Wallace issued a warrant for the arrest of this outlaw. Nicknamed for his youth, this outlaw was eventually shot in cold blood by Sheriff Pat Garrett.

Lew Wallace presided over the Union tribunal that tried and executed Confederate officer Henry Wirz, who commanded this Georgia prisoner-of-war camp where 13,000 Union captives died of disease and starvation.
answers_formatted: Billy the Kid [or William H. Bonney; or Henry McCarty]

bonuses.leadin: Name some aspects of fiscal policy in the US, for 10 points each:
answers: pump priming [or priming the pump; accept answers that include the words prime and pump]
OMB [or The Office of Management and Budget]
parts: Fiscal policy is pursued through adjustments in either government spending or tax rates, unlike this companion policy, which influences the economy through changing the money supply via interest rate manipulation.
This expression refers to stimulating aggregate demand through expansionary fiscal policy. Trump claimed to have invented this phrase, but it’s been used by Keynesians for 70 years.
This office, the largest within the executive branch and currently led by Mick Mulvaney, is tasked with overseeing the expenditures and regulations of the executive branch.
answers_formatted: pump priming [or priming the pump; accept answers that include the words prime and pump]
acceptable: answers that include the words prime and pump
The Office of Management and Budget

bonuses.leadin: The Mississippians were one of the most flourishing cultures that existed in North America before European landfall. For 10 points each:
parts: This site was the largest Mississippian settlement. At its peak in the 13th century, it had tens of thousands of residents, and 80 mounds remain on the site today, including Monk’s Mound.

Mississippians at Cahokia likely invented this game, where people threw spears at a disc-shaped stone rolling on the ground. Large crowds of fans bet on matches of this game, and the losers sometimes committed suicide.
The Mississippians, Hopewell, and Hohokam cultures all existed in the era before this explorer sailed the ocean blue in 1492.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, name some paintings with dogs, none of which are playing poker:
parts: This painter depicted a really cute spotted dog at the foot of a lounging nude woman in Venus of Urbino.
This artist painted a meta self-portrait-within-a-portrait; in it, his pug sits by a wooden palette carved with the S-shaped “line of beauty” he developed in his Analysis of Beauty.

The Danish Impressionist painting Summer Evening at Skagen Beach depicts this artist walking on a moonlit beach with his wife while their dog Rip sniffs his leg. This man was the leader of the Skagen Painters.

bonuses.leadin: One author of this religion described Shmuel, who serves as a companion to Gershom Wald, in Judas. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this religion, which Elie Wiesel described losing during the Holocaust in his novel Night.
This Jewish author wrote about his childhood in A Tale of Love and Darkness. In it, he discusses changing his name from Klausner in the context of his relationship with Israel.

This author wrote about a man who is tricked into urinating in bread in “Gimpel the Fool.” This author of The Family Moskat and The Penitent drew criticism for openly writing about controversial issues like lesbianism.

bonuses.leadin: Subtracting the strength of screening from this value gives the effective nuclear charge. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this value symbolized Z, which is equal to the number of protons in a nucleus.

This scientist showed that the mean ionization potential of an atom is equal to about 10 eV times the atomic number. This scientist also names a theorem giving the wavefunction of a particle in a periodic potential.
This potential is a one-dimensional periodic finite square well that can be solved using Bloch’s theorem.

bonuses.leadin: This hero touches a golden bowl which causes him to stick to it and lose the power of speech, but he is saved by Manawydan. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Welsh hero in the Mabinogion, who accompanies Bendigeidfran in his invasion of Ireland. This son of Rhiannon and Pwyll is killed by Gwydion over some traded pigs.
When Pryderi is young, he is found by Teyrnon after Rhiannon’s maids lose him and smear this animal’s blood onto Rhiannon to make it look like she had killed and eaten her child.

In the fourth branch of the Mabinogion, King Math will die unless he rests his feet in the lap of one of these people, including Goewin but not Arianrhod. In medieval myth, only these people can tame unicorns.

bonuses.leadin: For karyotyping, cells are arrested at this phase using vincristine or colchicine. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phase of mitosis in which condensed chromosomes line up in the center of the cell. It is immediately followed by anaphase.
At metaphase, chromatin has condensed into chromosomes. Chromatin is composed of DNA and these positively-charged proteins. A variant of them found in centromeres is called CENP-A.

Speaking of centromeres, this type of chromosome has its centromeres near the end, so the p arm is super short. Human chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22 are of this type, which are susceptible to Robertsonian translocation.

bonuses.leadin: This archaeologist coined the term “Fertile Crescent” in his high school textbook Ancient Times: A History of the New World. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this archaeologist who used money from John D. Rockefeller to found the Oriental Institute at the University of Chicago, for which he bought the mummy of the singer Meresamun.
The Rosetta Stone was a decree issued by Ptolemy V named for this city. Menes founded this city as the capital of the Old Kingdom, and it was home to a large temple to Ptah.
The town of Giza outside of Memphis is home to some of these tombs of the pharaohs.

bonuses.leadin: Fichte criticized this author’s “Presentation of My System of Philosophy,” since he thought philosophy could not be personalized. For 10 points each:
answers: Great Britain [or the United Kingdom; prompt on England (since the movement is consistently referred to as British Idealism)]
parts: Name this German idealist whose Naturphilosophie was meant in part to counter Fichte’s Wissenschaftslehre (VISS-un-schaft-slare).
Schelling was university roommates and later rivals with this other German philosopher, who formulated the master-slave dialectic in his The Phenomenology of Spirit.

Hegel, Fichte, and Schelling’s work had a significant influence on the idealist movement of this country. This country’s idealists so irritated Moore and Russell that they created analytic philosophy as a “revolt” against them.
metadata: since the movement is consistently referred to as British Idealism

bonuses.leadin: One of these substances is made of self emulsion agar, and a spacecraft called Stardust uses an array of these substances to collect space dust. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these substances, in which the liquid component of a colloid is replaced with gas.

The first aerogels were made from this element, crystals of which are formed in the Czochralski process. This element lies right underneath carbon on the periodic table and is commonly used in semiconductors.
One method of forming aerogels relies on a form of drying done in this phase. CO2 in this phase is used to decaffeinate coffee.

bonuses.leadin: You should go to church on Sunday, but you should also go on other days too. For 10 points each:
parts: Going to church is required of all Catholics on these important non-Sunday days. They include Epiphany, All Saints Day, and Corpus Christi.
Attendees at regular old weekday Mass may notice that the Gloria and the Creed are omitted and that the number of non-Gospel readings is this number rather than the two at a Sunday Mass.

Weekday mass got less exciting in 1969, when Paul VI dropped a bunch of saints off the official calendar of feast days, including this patron saint of travelers who legendarily carried the Christ Child across a river.

bonuses.leadin: This novel describes the Statue of Liberty holding a sword instead of a torch. For 10 points each:
answers: Amerika [or The Man Who Disappeared or The Missing Person or Der Verschollene]
parts: Name this unfinished novel about Karl Rossman, who meets his uncle Senator Jacob, is ripped off by Robinson and Delamarche, and leaves for the Nature Theatre of Oklahoma.
In a short story by the author of Amerika, this singer makes music for her community of “mouse folk” by whistling and then disappears to be forgotten.
Amerika and “Josephine the Songstress of the Mouse Folk” were written by this author, whose parable “Before the Law” is told to Josef K. in The Trial.
answers_formatted: Amerika [or The Man Who Disappeared or The Missing Person or Der Verschollene]

bonuses.leadin: WWII-era Germany marked a tumultuous time for conductors. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this idiosyncratic Romanian conductor who became the conductor of Berlin Phil after Leo Borchard was killed at a traffic stop. This spiritual conductor is probably best known for his distaste for recording performances and rebuilding the Berlin Philharmonic after WWII.

Both Celibidache and Borchard served as replacements for Wilhelm Furtwangler, who raised the ire of the Nazis after conducting this banned Hindemith opera about the creator of the Isenheim Altarpiece.

Another conductor affected by the rise of the Nazis was Otto Klemperer, who fled Nazi Germany to become the music director of this American orchestra. This orchestra is currently directed by Gustavo Dudamel.

bonuses.leadin: A courtyard of this name is located in the Great Mosque of Cordoba. For 10 points each:
answers: oranges [or Court of Oranges; War of the Oranges; naranjas; laranjas]
parts: Give this word that also names a conflict in which Manuel Godoy sponsored an invasion of Portugal, which ended in the Peace of Badajoz. That conflict gained its name from these objects that Godoy sent to Maria Luisa.

This Spanish city names a bitter type of orange that grows there. The Almohads significantly enlarged a palace in this city called the Alcazar, and an etymological encyclopedia was written by a Saint from here named Isidore.

Valencia, while famed as a producer of oranges, was captured by El Cid, who was a general during this conflict. Ferdinand and Isabella’s capture of Granada ended this campaign to retake Spain from the Muslims.
answers_formatted: oranges [or Court of Oranges; War of the Oranges; naranjas; laranjas]

bonuses.leadin: This nation formerly colonized by British rule has had a censor called the Press Scrutiny and Registration Board. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, whose Thakin Kodaw Hmaing defined its anti-colonial literature and led a nationalist movement.

This debatably autobiographical short story set in Burma ends with the narrator grateful for a dead native because it justifies the mostly prideful. The narrator takes the title action to “avoid looking like a fool.”
George Orwell, author of “Shooting an Elephant,” created this phrase, an inverse use of language where the meaning of words becomes irrelevant as they refer to their opposite, in 1984.

bonuses.leadin: This function has type a to b to f a to f b. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this function that given a function, lifts it to another function that can apply the original function to every element of a list.
Map is used in these kinds of programming languages, examples of which include Haskell. Map and fold are “higher-order” instances of its title concepts.
Another neat feature of functional languages are these constructs, borrowed by Python, which let you write things like “for n in 1 through 10, n squared” to make a list of the first 10 squares.

bonuses.leadin: Stamford Raffles’s planning ordinances mandated that these dwellings be abutted by a continuous covered walkway at least five feet in width. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these residences ubiquitous in Singapore and much of the rest of southeast Asia. Traditionally, they contained personal and family spaces on the upper floors, with the street level reserved for conducting business.
More luxurious Singaporean accommodations are available in this resort designed by Moshe Safdie. Its three towers are linked at their tops by a 340-meter “SkyPark.”

This architect’s works in Singapore include the OCBC Centre tower and The Gateway, a pair of trapezoidally planned skyscrapers. He also designed the East Building of the National Gallery of Art in Washington DC.
